title: Recommendations for dynamic allowance in bridge assessment
segmentation: Thank you.
And so our previous speaker spoke about the.
About the.
Static load on bridges.
I'm going to talk about the dynamics, so I'm going to talk about a little bit of introduction.

I'm going to talk then about general recommendations on dynamic allowances for all types of bridges, and Thirdly, then on specific recommendations for a site specific assessment of what do you, what allowance do you make for dynamics?
And then some conclusions.

So finding the characteristics, static load effect, the load effect with an acceptably low probability, that's what burners and I talked about just now, so I'll accept starting from that point and see how do we go from there.
Alternatively, we might in some countries they have a notional load model used for assessment, so in the UK for example, they have a specified vehicle for which they check.
They used to assess the safety of bridges, but either way you have to make some sort of an allowance for dynamics.
So how do you do that?
So that's that's the purpose of this presentation.
This.

This slide from allege need rich in Zag, and this these are measurements that indicate that dynamic amplification tends to reduce as the weight of the truck that's causing it or the the criticality of the event is increasing.
So as you go to heavier vehicles, that tends to be a downward trend in the dynamic dynamic amplification.
So we have some reason to believe that the allowances for dynamics at the moment or Arkansas.
Relative, and that perhaps the extreme situations they are not very high.
So I'm going to start with a general allowance for all bridges.
We saw this picture before.
This is one of these very heavy cranes.
Wait in the Netherlands.

The previous studies for dynamics considered some very common trucks, so in the Divine project in the OECD defined project some years ago, for example, they consider two excellent 5 axle trucks crossing bridges.
We now know from the artist project that the critical loading events are usually cranes or low loaders and there has no work been done before on the dynamics of these types of bagels.
So we started to do a study to compare 5X of trucks with cranes.
So we have.
This is a computer simulation type study, so we have a computer model of A5 axle truck and a computer model of a crane and.
We did a lot of computer simulation using those two models, so we have two types of model.
One is quite simple, it's just a beam model.
It's order.
Bernoulli is standard type of beam.
It's not very accurate because bridges of course are three dimensional, not not one dimensional.
Conservative, though, tends to be conservative, and it's very fast.
It's very quick to calculation.
We also did plate models, so finite element 2D model with all the mode shapes, so that's more accurate, of course, but it takes longer to run, so we can't afford to do so many calculation.
With that model.

An we took data directly from the way in motion measurements, so the burden size in the Netherlands and from there we picked 77 daily maximum vehicles, 77 daily maximum cranes and the corresponding daily maximum 5 axle trucks.
And then we did a lot of random simulation, Monte Carlo type simulations.

We took a lot of different Rd profiles with Class A or Class B, so smooth and a little bit rougher, and we took a lot of different vagle properties, so we assumed different vehicle speeds, suspension types, tire stiffness is, and so on.
So we randomly varied all these parameters we did over 300,000 beam simulations.
And 50,000 plate model simulations, so quite a lot of computers running students beavering away at computers for many days, and we considered the Class A and Class B Rd profiles separately.
So these are some of the results, so this is dynamic amplification factor for bending moment.
It's the beam model.
It's a simple model.
The green is A5 axle truck, the blue is a crane type truck type vehicle and these are 95% confidence intervals for smooth Rd profiles.
So you can see that generally speaking, the dynamic amplification for the 5X and vehicle is a fair bit greater than for the crane type vehicles.
Anne.
That was for the simple beam model.
We also ran it for plate models, so we couldn't do as many runs here, so we pick just three different spans, and for those three spans we did some simulations down here.
So again, the green is A5 axle trucks and the cranes.

The blue is the cranes, so generally speaking the blue is below the green, suggesting that the cranes or less have less dynamic amplification than the five axle trucks, and these are the confidence interval values here.
So again, the blue is below the green.
In two of the cases here, it's not below it, but it's very close to it.
I'm also noticing that at the plate model tends to be show less dynamic amplification than the B model, so the model does tend to be conservative.
So finally we make a recommendation.
So our suggestion is that an allowance for dynamics in general for bridges should perhaps go from 30% allowance for very short spans down to 15% for anything above 15 meters, so it's simple.
It's easy to remember 30% to 15%.
And it's generally conservative, so the blue is the crane type loading event and we're more conservative than that in all cases.
Anne.
This is the eurocode recommendation so far.
One Lane bridges, so we're talking about one truck only.
Events were not talking about meeting events for one Lane.
Bridges in Eurocode there are making recommendations of up to 70%.
For a bending moment and 40% for shear force.
So they're much, much more conservative, so our suggestion is is down here.
It's much, much better with your code is suggesting at the moment, so that was for Class A type roads.
So when the road is quite smooth you would normally expect a highway type situation to have a smooth Rd, so that seems reasonable enough, but we checked.
Class B Type Rd surface is, well, an Oak.
Need to go through it all again but we we repeated all those simulations.
And we came up this time with.
A bit more dynamics that you'd expect the roads are rougher, and our recommendation for this type of Rd surface will be allowance varying from 40% to 20%.
So from 30% to 15% for Class A rose and from 40% to 20%.
Rougher roads for Class B roads.
That was for one one truck crossing events which really only applies for one Lane bridges and I fully accept that one Lane bridges are pretty unusual type of thing.

Most bridges would have more than one Lane, but these recommendations would be conservative for two Lane bridges, so it would be safe to make the same assumptions for two Lane bridges, but we were at the moment in the process of doing a study for two Lane bridges, so we're looking at critical loading events.
Two or more vehicles meeting on the bridge.
We need to do about 100 computer days of computer simulations before we would have results.
For that we will have results in the next month or so.
And we expect considerably reduced allowances for dynamics for multilane bridges as well as they were for one end.
So that was dynamic allowance for all types of bridges.
We also looked at specific recommendations.
What do you do if you have a particular bridge that you're concerned about?
It may have some corrosion issues and what sort of dynamic.
Once do you allow for there?
So the idea is that you could directly measure total strain.
Of course you can put sensors on the bridge at the first speaker, talked about and measure total strain.
You could also use way in Motion system as is being done in Slovenia here too.
Get the weight of the trucks that caused the strain and then you could back calculate to find the static strain corresponding to the measure total strength.
So that would give you an estimate of the dynamic amplification factor for a bridge, so you can actually measure dynamic damper.
Patience factor.
An we did this at four different sites.
Travinia Francisco lack of its and the Netherlands.
Four different types of bridges.
They all had Wayne Bridge when Motion systems on them.
Different numbers of days and different numbers of.
Dance.
And these are some of the typical results, so this is dynamic application on one axis against the static strain.
The general trend is downwards.
So the dynamic application is getting less as you get into the more critical events.
Same trend we already observed, and there's a mean result there and confidence interval value there so.
We have these.
Four different sites.
Which I.
Want to lay on?
And all of these are dynamic amplification factors.
So partway through this artist research, we started to ask ourselves, is dynamic amplification factor actually?
The most appropriate measure of dynamic allowance because atomic amplification factor is the dynamic stress divided by the static stress for a given loading scenario.
For a given truck, perhaps, or.
Eating 2 trucks.
We developed a new factor for dynamics, which is a little bit different, so we difficult and ADR, which is the ratio of what you want to know to what you actually know at the moment.

So what you want to know is the characteristic statistically acceptable, acceptably improbable, total stress, considering all possible types of loading scenarios divided by the characteristic static stress which the previous speaker talked about, how we might find that.
So we would normally have that from a static study.
And that gives you quite different results, so you can illustrate the ADR concept here from this graph.
So we have a graph of static stress versus total stress, so these are different loading scenarios.
In each case, you've got the total and you've got the static.
And the total stress with an acceptably low probability of happening might be that level, and the static equivalent might be that level, and then it's just it's that point is the slope of that line.
That would be the ADR and it would be the assessment dynamic.
So they were looking for.
And we did some field measurements of total stress and corresponding static so.
This little bit complicated graph.
So the first thing we have here, solid red line is the maximum measured total bending moment, so total stress or total strength.
So we measured it and we took the maximum we found.
So this graph continues to increase every time you find a bigger one.
You plot that, so it's versus number of trucks or time on this axis.
And then we got the corresponding static value, so that's this one.
Its estimate of maximum static and again that increases overtime.
But what we're looking for is the ratio of the two, so the ratio of the two might get bigger or smaller.
We found that it bounces around.

The third one is the ratio of the two, is the assessment dynamic ratio, and it does bounce around the place quite a bit in the beginning, but after about a months worth of trucks, it settles down and after that it generally only decreases.
So after about a month you should have a conservative estimate of the allowance.
I'm nearly finished.
And so we're saying that if you measure.

An total strain and static strain over a period of time that it varies quite a bit in the beginning if you do it over a short period time, it varies quite a lot, and the more you measure, the less variation in this parameter and that by the time you get to about a months worth of data you should have a very good.
You should have a pretty good estimate of the lifetime maximum.
It's for dynamics.
So in conclusion.
There's a great deal of conservatism in the eurocodes your code is making huge allowances for dynamics.
We are recommending something considerably less.
But at the moment it's only for one Lane bridges, but it would be conservative for multi then.
Just.
And for particular bridges, it's often possible to show that there are even more conservatism in the allowances.
So we recommend using Bridgeway in motion to estimate the static measured.
The total strain directly.
And after I say for safety, I would say three months of data should be good enough to get a good estimate of the assessment dynamic ratio.
Thank you.
